question_data.explanation: This requires integrating three key relationships: (1) Mass determines nuclear fusion rate (higher mass = faster fuel consumption = shorter lifespan), (2) Mass dictates gravitational collapse strength (higher mass enables supernovae rather than planetary nebula ejection), and (3) Mass governs remnant formation thresholds (black holes require >20 solar masses, neutron stars ~8-20, white dwarfs <8). The correct answer synthesizes fuel consumption rates, stellar evolution timelines, and compact object formation criteria.

D) A star's mass determines only its color and temperature, not its lifespan or remnant type
